awd_titl_txt: Travel: Support for Conference Participation at the ACM Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support student attendance at the 2024 version of the Intelligent User Interfaces (IUI) conference to be held in Greenville, South Carolina. IUI is the main international conference where researchers in human computer interaction (HCI) and artificial intelligence (AI) present work on systems that use AI to help people be more effective in interacting with computers. IUI research spans a wide range of socially important topics and domains, including recommender systems, adaptive educational systems, accessibility, autonomous systems, creativity, virtual agents, and many others. Providing travel funding that allows junior researchers to present their own work and be enriched by others' work will strengthen the IUI community and provide valuable benefits for the students involved.

The funding will support around 14 students to attend the conference. Most of these students will also attend a Doctoral Consortium at which later-stage PhD students will present and get feedback on their dissertation research from both senior researchers and other PhD students in the IUI community. The availability of travel funding will be widely announced in the relevant communities, with students being invited to submit applications describing their doctoral work. These applications will be reviewed by a program committee that gives substantive feedback for every application, whether accepted or not. Acceptance decisions will be made with an eye toward topical, institutional, and demographic diversity of participants, while also considering financial need. Chosen students will attend a day-long doctoral consortium, have additional opportunities to meet with individual mentors, and be invited to present in a poster session for the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) community has been well-developed, and the joint effort of HCI and artificial intelligence (AI) has been influential various areas of applications, including (but is in no way limited to) recommender systems, adaptive educational systems, intelligent user interfaces, e-commerce, advertising, digital humanities, social networks, personalized health, entertainment, applications oriented to users with different disabilities, and many more. ACM IUI is where the HCI community meets the AI community. ACM IUI is the annual meeting of the intelligent interfaces community and serves as a premier international forum for reporting outstanding research and development on intelligent user interfaces. Active participation of young researchers in this conference is very important for the health of the field and for the researchers themselves. Thus, by bringing young and creative researchers to the IUI conferences, the requested funds will help advance an important and socially valuable research field.  


This NSF grant offers funds to support travel of students currently enrolled in M.S. or Ph.D. programs in U.S. institutions to attend the ACM Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces. Particularly, priority will be given to the PhD student who will present in the Doctoral Consortium at the IUI conference, where students can get feedbacks about their research from selected mentors. The remaining funds for students will be used to support the PhD and/or Master students who have accepted submissions at IUI. 


PI has utilized the funding from this grant to support 14 and 3 students to attend the IUI 2024 and 2025 conferences, respectively. This activity supports the mission of NSF and other granting agencies to train more advanced professionals in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). Attending conferences is difficult and expensive for students. Funding travel for graduate students has a broader impact.


Last Modified: 04/14/2025
Modified by: Yong Zheng
